titleInfo.title: Louisiana Cooperative Extension Oral History Project
titleInfo.subTitle: Billy Cochran oral history interview, 2014

name.description: Billy J. Cochran was born on December 10, 1933, in Darbun, Mississippi. He is the son of Arville Alexander Cochran and Gertrude Lewis. He attended rural Mississippi schools during his youth. In 1958 he graduated with a B.S. degree in agricultural engineering from Mississippi State University. Upon graduation, he served for a short time in the United States Army, and then returned to school at Texas A&M University. In 1962 he graduated with a master's degree in agricultural engineering. In 1964 he joined the faculty at Louisiana State University where he taught in the Agricultural Engineering Department. During the early seventies, he took a sabbatical from LSU and earned a Ph.D. in agricultural engineering from Oklahoma State University. After retiring from LSU in 1983, he worked abroad with the International Rice Research Institute and the Food and Agriculture Organization in Thailand. From 1992 to 1996 he worked for the Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service as a solid waste specialist. He lives in Baton Rouge, La., with his wife, Jintana.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

mods.abstract: Cochran begins the interview by discussing his parents' cotton farm. He also talks about life in a rural school and moving to the city of Columbia where he had his first job as a paperboy for the New Orleans Item. The interview then moves into a discussion about his education at Mississippi State, Texas A&M, and Oklahoma State Universities. He documents his time as an LSU professor, an international consultant in the field of agriculture, and his time as a solid waste specialist for the Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service.
